Michael Holly wrote:

> What is wrong with the concept of a defineable, repeatable, managed,
> optimized software development
> process?

Process definitions don't write software; people do.

 > Where would we be if Jules Verne had not dreamed of going to the
> moon? Or Columbus
> going to the New World?  Both events happened( regardless of what some small
> fringe group say ).

I dream of someone giving me $10M, but that dream goes against basic 
human nature. That is why it remains a dream.

The dreams you mention here go *with* human nature -- namely the desire 
to explore -- and that helped make them happen.

> The point I'm making is that if you do not have goals then you won't get the
> benefits of reaching
> even part of your goal.

 From what I understand the goal of CMM is to define a process that even 
a monkey could follow. Monkeys do not write software; people do.

> Don't get me wrong. I have been on the butt end of an Enterprise CMM effort.
> It's mucho annoying,
> however, the underlying goal is still valid and drives toward better
> software.

It drives towards more uniform results, certainly; but I don't know 
about "better software".
